templates.name: Allergens
templates.content: Our ice cream-making machinery at The New Dairy is constructed of stainless steel. It's cleaned frequently and thoroughly throughout the production day to eliminate the possibility of pathogen transmission and allergen residue. For this reason, there's an exceptionally small risk of residue "carry over." If you're extremely sensitive to allergens, including gluten, wheat, soy, milk, and/or tree nuts, please note that all of our ice creams, sorbets, variegates and inclusions are produced and/or processed using the same equipment.

templates.name: How do you ship your ice cream?
templates.content: We ship our ice creams inside an insulated frozen shipper box, packed with dry ice to ensure your purchase arrives at its destination in perfect condition, within the time frame it's supposed to arrive. Please note that dry ice is exceptionally cold (-109.3°F). With each box, we include specific instructions to provide for safe handling and disposal of any remaining dry ice.

templates.name: Where does your dairy come from?
templates.content: While McConnell's is a working dairy (The Old Dairy), we're now exclusively a dairy processing facility. McC's exited the dairy farming business in the mid-1960's when land values on the Central Coast skyrocketed. It was simply no longer feasible at that point to manage our own cows. Since that time, McConnell's has sourced our raw milk & cream from Producers Dairy, The Shehadey Family's 83-year-old dairy, based in Central California.

templates.name: How do I soften the ice cream when it's too frozen?
templates.content: The best thing to do, if you want to maximize the flavor of your ice cream, is to let the ice cream soften a bit or temper. Ice cream's flavor is actually suppressed the colder the product is. As it warms up - just a bit - the flavor of the ice cream will notably increase, resulting in maximum enjoyment for you and your guests (that is, if you're kind enough to share). We recommend you let your ice cream sit out on the counter if only for a few minutes. Your taste buds will love you!

templates.name: Are your products 100% organic?
templates.content:
At McConnell's, we have one goal: to make the finest ice creams! We achieve this by having exceptionally high standards across the board. To maintain these standards, it's critical that every ingredient in our ice creams be of the highest
quality. While we're ardent supporters of organics in general, in our almost 70 years as a dairy, it's been our experience that milk & cream can vary greatly in quality and consistency. Inconsistency in milk & cream can be traced to any number of factors, including animal husbandry, pasture type and processing. The milk & cream we use comes from cows raised by local dairy co-ops on the Central
Coast. It's grass-grazed, hormone and antibiotic free, and of exceptionally high quality. It's important to know that organic is a term that defines a process, rather than objective quality. There's wonderful and not-so-wonderful organic milk in the market, just as there's wonderful and not-so-wonderful organic fruit, nuts, chocolate, etc. 

While organic is certainly an important factor when it comes to selecting ingredients for McConnell's Fine Ice Creams, committing wholly to organics - over objective quality - would mean McConnell's valued a specific process over making the finest product we can make and this is unacceptable to us. I hope this informaiton was helpful!

templates.name: What is “Tapioca Starch”?
templates.content: Tapioca Starch is a plant-based product made from the dried, ground-up pulp from the root of the cassava tree. We use a small amount of tapioca starch, paired with milk protein concentrate to help hold together our products when they're under stress and to ward-off the challenges of the supply chain, such as thawing/re-freezing and "heat shock".

templates.name: Did you change your ingredients? Your ice cream tastes different than it used to
templates.content:
Over time, as our ice creams have come to be available in grocery stores across the country, we have seen what can happen to ice cream on the shelves of a grocery store with a "challenged freezer" in the heat of the summer. The answer: Nothing good. Our dilemma was how to protect our ice creams from the realities of supply chain - on the way to customers' home freezers while continuing to make our ice creams using the finest ingredients.

We came up with a solution that's truly unique in our industry. We've formulated a combination of Dairy Protein Concentrate and a small amount of Tapioca Starch. The Milk Protein Concentrate is a by-product of micro-filtering the proteins from raw milk. What you get is concentrated protein and the Tapioca Starch is a fine powder made from the dried, ground-up pulp from the root of the cassava tree. We've run countless tests, across every one of our flavors, for taste, texture, consistency and the like. We are over-the-moon excited about this development. The ice creams are actually better. Creamier, smoother, more consistent - and everything we'd hoped for!

templates.name: What is “Milk Protein Concentrate”?
templates.content: It's simply a by-product of micro-filtering the proteins from raw milk. What you get is concentrated protein (hence the name MPC). We use milk protein concentrate - paired with a small amount of tapioca starch - to ward-off the challenges of the supply chain, such as thawing/re-freezing and "heat shock". One of the great things about using MPC is that it allows us to reduce the sugar contents of our ice creams as milk proteins are naturally sweet!

templates.name: Products too expensive - brand specific
templates.content:
We understand that our product is more expensive than some of the other brands in the freezer aisle. McConnell's is far more expensive to produce than any other ice cream we know of. This is a function of the quality and cost of ingredients and our commitment to doing things our way and to controlling the process, every step of the way. We use better quality ingredients across the board, and we use more of those ingredients, from vanilla to chocolate, etc. Add to this the fact that our product has virtually no air in it (it's called overrun) - less than 10%, versus our closest competitors, whose products contain 40%+ air. But here's the thing: our customers end up getting what they pay for and to us, that's what really matters.

Unfortunately, we also do not set the price in grocery stores. Our retailers are in control of that, and while we do work with them to manage pricing, if their desire is to set a certain margin on our products, we simply cannot control that. McConnell's is a truly made from scratch product - the only one in the freezer aisle that we're aware of. This is significant because it makes for the finest product in the business. And while it may cost a bit more, we think it's worth it. And we hope you ultimately feel the same way.

templates.name: Why are online prices more expensive than at grocery stores?
templates.content:
We know it is slightly more expensive to buy online than in grocery stores, and totally understand how frustrating that can be. I know when it comes down to it, it really doesn't matter the reason, but we want you to know that our prices cover the costs of everything that goes into shipping ice cream across the country, including labor, dry ice, packing materials, and warehouse storage fees. Shipping ice cream truly is tricky business! Please know that we are actively pursuing opportunities to reduce costs associated with shipping our ice cream. We'll continue to optimize our shipping and fulfillment process and look forward to
lowering these prices in the near future.

templates.name: Why is the ice cream I purchased in store“icy”?/The ice cream I purchased was awful, refrozen, etc.
templates.content:
First of all, thank you sincerely for reaching out to us. While we're almost as upset as you are at the condition of the ice cream you purchased, the only way we're able to address a situation such as this is to have customers who care - or who are upset enough - to actually contact us. For this, I'm grateful! 

At McConnell's, we are - more than any company I've ever seen - obsessed with quality. We pay huge attention to every aspect of our product - including
maintaining a full-time QA professional - and that means making sure that every pint that leaves the dairy is perfect. Unfortunately, regardless of our intention, one thing we don't control is what happens to our products once they've left the dairy. But here's the thing - that's not your issue. It's ours. And our products should be perfect every time.

Most importantly, we would appreciate the opportunity to make this right! If you'd kindly provide your mailing address, we would love to send you some coupons so you can try McConnell's again, on us. It's the least we can do to let you see what McConnell's ice creams are really supposed to be.

templates.name: I found a hair in my pint ( This can be used for bug/plastic but EDIT before sending)
templates.content:
First, we do apologize for your finding a hair in your ice cream. Your reaction is certainly warranted. The most important thing is for us to remedy the situation. Here at McConnell's, we do everything we can to accomplish one thing: make the finest ice creams on Earth. We achieve this by having exceptionally high standards across the board. This includes hair and beard nets, which typically provide an excellent barrier to something like this from ever occurring. But sometimes - and frankly, I can't explain how - things do happen. 

As a dairy and manufacturer, the most important thing we know about our business is this: we're not in the food business, we're in the food safety business. And while we can't ever know exactly how this hair found its way into your pint, we can commit to you that we'll continue to be vigilant in doing everything we can to eliminate the possibility of something like this happening.

If you kept the pint, can you please forward the code from the bottom of that pint. This will allow us to further our efforts as we investigate the issue. In the meantime, if you'd be kind enough to do so, please forward your mailing address. We'd love to offer you some free ice cream, sent straight to your home, as a token of our appreciation for bringing this to our attention. Your comments actually help us get better at what we do.
